I think it's neat to say that the Taylor series goes on to be equal to the function as we take on more sums, because in a way, we are zooming out(such that the 'neighbourhood' is extending farther outwards), and the higher order derivatives control the farther terms to 'accommodate the extending neighbourhood'.
Since, we can zoom out infinitely, from some frame of observation(i.e. some scaling factor), we can say that performing a 'level one accommodation' in this frame, is equivalent to say, a 'level four accommodation' in a less wider frame, as long as the 'accommodations' are of the same kind(which is not the case for divergent neighbourhoods), like our original non-zoomed out frame.

You mention how the Taylor series for x=0 perfectly approximates exp(x) for any x, and how ln(x) has a much more limited but still significant vicinity of x=1 where the approximation is absolute if you sum up the whole infinite series.
 
There's another interesting example where the Taylor series while being fully valid and correctly approximating the function at x=0 nonetheless for any value of x however close to zero the approximation is very very limited and adding up all the infinite members of the Taylor series doesn't help. 

Here's an example of such function:    f(0) = 0, f(x) = exp(-1/(x^2)) if x=/=0

As x approaches 0 this function approaches zero faster than any polynomial of any degree. So any derivative of this function is equal to zero at x=0. In other words, the Taylor series for this function is trivial and all the members of it are zeroes.

Yet clearly the value of this function is equal to 0 only at x=0. So at any point x however close to 0 (besides the 0 itself) - using the Taylor series for x=0 as a "calculator" for the value of f(x) is not going to work.

One of the things that holds me back from learning stuff like this is my brain arguing with itself. It makes such arguments as:
_"Why do I need this, when I can find the exact value with a calculator?
Am I supposed to pretend that we don't know how to do this the proper, quick way?
Where would this be used in real life?
Why do we need to know this?"_
If my brain knows that a particular method can be useful in the real world, and it's not just part of a history lesson, it seems to pay a lot more attention. Like minimisation problems, and rates of change, etc..
But if it knows that there's a faster, easier way to do something it just refuses to learn it unless I find a good enough reason to convince it..
Even knowing that I could do a calculation like this and get a good approximation if I didn't have a calculator handy, might be enough to convince my brain to learn it.

this is what I do for simplicity

let cos(x) = c1

dy/dx = c1 + c2x

d^2y/dx^2 = c1 + c2x + c3x^2
...

cos(0) = 1 therefore c1 = 1

-sin 0 is 0 so the other side has to equal to 0 and solve for c

dy/dx cos(0) = -sin(0) = 0 = 0 + c2 = 0

we take first derivative and differenciate it again. With cosine turns into -cosine. cos(0) = 1 so -cos(0) = -1 so left side also equals -1. Everything except c3x^2 turns into 0 and we solve. We get -1 = 2c3x^0 which simplifies to -1 = 2c3 where c3 = -1/2
what if you have the coefficients of the Taylor series and want to known which function it represents?

After much thought, I must disagree. It has been proved as n -> infinity, the sum of terms that equal 1/2 becomes infinitely large ( 2: 1/4, 4: 1/8, 8: 1/16, . . .), but the actual value becomes increasingly small (2x(1/4)+4x(1/8)+8x(1/16)+16x(1/32) . . .). The harmonic series starts at 1 and converges on 2. This result says absolutely nothing about the harmonic series diverging, as the new series is below the harmonic series and this new series converges to zero. I have always believed the harmonic series elements converge to zero as n -> infinity and still do. It must be remembered that the graph we see gives the actual value of each element, the behavior of the harmonic series starts at 1 and arches up towards 2 at infinity. 2 is its limiting number.

In AP Calculus BC, when Taylor Series were introduced, I was simply confused. It seemed as if my teacher was simply getting formulas out of thin air. I proceeded to memorize the formulas and do well in the class. But not until watching this amazing video did I really understand what was going on! The idea of approximating a function through taking many higher order derivatives at one point is simply mind blowing.

After thinking about the video, I now realize the importance of the many tests for series convergence that we had to learn. Taylor polynomials are created to model functions that have real life applications in physics and engineering, and the best approximations we have are Taylor series. We need all the tests for series convergence in order to determine whether or not the Taylor series that we create will actually provide an approximation that will be accurate at a given point! If the Taylor series is divergent then it won't approximate at all, if it is conditionally convergent it will approximate only within the interval of convergence, and if it is convergent then it will approximate everywhere. Awesome stuff! And people say math isn't fun...

is there such a thing as a "minimum" Radius of convergence or can it be calculated? In other words, if you extended the taylor series for ln(x)=(x-1) infinitely would the divergence cascade down to the to the point x = 1?

If your wondering why its called a "radius of convergence", its because, when you take a taylor series in the complex numbers, you get a circle centered on the point you expanded around. The radius of the circle is the distance from the center to the nearest singularity. (point where everything goes 1/0)
Exponentials, and sin and cos are defined over all complex numbers, so converge on all complex numbers.
1/(1+x^2) has a radius of convergence 1, because it has a singularity at i. (root -1)
I don't think the explanations are very rigorous, although they may be intuitive.

Un dessin du polycopié (page 4 du chapitre) présente sur un même graphique les approximations de la fonction sin par la partie principale de son DL en 0, jusqu'à l'ordre 7.
En fait, il n'est pas très convaincant que cela illustre bien le sujet. Expliquons-nous : un DL est un renseignement local, on peut donc être content de l'approximation dès qu'elle a lieu localement, ce qui sur le dessin correspond à l'existence d'un petit morceau de courbe autour de 0 où on ne peut distinguer s'il s'agit du sinus ou du polynôme qui l'approche. De ce point de vue local en 0, les polynômes de plus haut degré n'apportent pas plus que l'on puisse voir sur le dessin. Ce que l'on voit sur le dessin, quand l'ordre du DL augmente, c'est plutôt un renseignement de nature différente, l'agrandissement de la portion où les courbes coïncident.
Une version animée assez spectaculaire est présentée dans la vidéo (à +1'53"). Notez que sur un écran, la limite de distinction des courbes (la résolution du tracé) est clairement définie par le pixel.

Comment pourriez-vous modifier le type d'animation dans la vidéo pour illustrer ce caractère local qui nous importe avec les DL ? Quand l'ordre augmente, l'approximation devient meilleure, localement en 0. Comment le faire voir ? Il faudrait, par exemple, que l'on puisse continuer à distinguer  sinxsin⁡x  d'avec  x−x36x−x36 , idéalement jusqu'au pixel 0, et que les courbes   y=x−x36+x5120y=x−x36+x5120   et   y=sinxy=sin⁡x   coïncident, elles, sur une petite portion contenant 0. Puis que l'on puisse itérer cela à l'ordre suivant ...

For those of you who are wondering how information from a single point would give information about the entire curve in the region,
Imagine a case where you are dealing with a discrete function. Here let us suppose to find the Taylor polynomial at x = 0. When we calculate the derivative at x=0, we calculate [x(1) - x(0)]/(1-0) = x(1)-x(0) {assuming forward derivatives}. So, in calculating the first derivative we have used information about the value of the function in the adjoining point x=1. In general, we are using the information about the next point in calculating the first derivative at that point.
The second derivative at x=0 is calculated with the formula [x'(1) - x'(0)]/(1-0) = [x'(1) - x'(0)]. From the above statement we can conclude that value of the function at x = 2 is used to calculate x'(1) which is the first derivative of the function at x = 1. So, while calculating the second derivative, we are using the information of the next two points. In general, in calculating the nth order derivative, we are using information about n next points.

Speaking of Taylor Polynomials and Taylor Series, of all the various proofs of Euler's formula (including your own proofs here on your own channel), the one that actually made the most sense to me mathematically was the Taylor Series proof of Euler's formula, using the Taylor Series expansions of e^x, sin(x), and cos(x) as well as the formula e^ix = cos(x) + i sin(x).

And when you plug π into x, you end up with -1 = -1. And therefore, e^iπ = cos(π) + i sin(π) = -1.

The other day I had an insight about the taylor series for e^x I've never come across before. So e^x is what you get when you invest $1 at 100% annual interest, compounded continuously, for x years. This is usually shown by compounding a finite number of times, and letting the width of each compounding interval approach zero (and letting the number of time periods approach infinity). But another way to look at it is to start with the principle, which has a value of $1 over the entire duration. The simple interest on that principle is given by x, so it increases linearly. This is also the integral of the principle over time. But the interest ON that interest, say the secondary interest, is the integral of the simple interest term - that's (x^2)/2. And the interest on the secondary interest, in turn, is the integral of the secondary interest - (x^3)/6. Continuing on the same way, the entire amount in the account after x years is just the taylor series for e^x, where each term is the interest earned on the previous term.

Please justify in a video the use of differentials :( It's really the main thing that bothered me throughout this series considering your impact with the high quality of presentation. So much misunderstanding can be avoided if you do.

If y=f(x) linear, then it is its own tangent, because the slope of all secants Δy/Δx = m is equal to the slope of the tangent at every point dy/dx = m leading to Δy/Δx = dy/dx and thereby suggesting that ON THE TANGENT ONLY the symbol/linear operator acting on y called dy/dx behaves like a fraction and can be manipulated like one. Because differentiable functions are locally linear, we can make a very good linear approximation by only considering its tangent locally and thereby enable the use of differentials by the justification above, yielding the simplification f(x+dx)≈f(x)+df, where df=f'(x)dx. This gives computational tools like finding f(x)=x^3 at x=4.25 and doing so by linear approximation with the tangent at x=4, i.e. f(4+1/4)≈4^3+3*(4^2)*1/4=64+12=76 - still very close to the actual value f(4,25)=76,77. There is abundant use of this property in engineering and physics - making drawings and considering changes small enough to be considered linear and then abusing the hell out of differentials.

Maybe pointing out how Leibniz used differentials and how it connects with modern limit notation: Perceive locally linear functions as literally being composed of line segments between to points (x,y) and (x+dx,y+dy), i.e. slope dy/dx and computing derivatives with that idea - i.e. y=x^2 => y+dy=(x+dx)^2 <=> dy=2x*dx (discarding dx^2) <=> dy/dx = 2x. And in modern notation: y+Δy = (x+Δx)^2 <=> Δy/Δx = 2x+Δx <=> dy/dx = lim Δx -> 0 2x+Δx = 2x.

(in more detail: Simmons, George F. Calculus with Analytic Geometry. 2nd ed. p. 168)

The Taylor series for x^x is not even the addition of polynomial terms. The Taylor series for x^x is 1 + xlnx + (xlnx)^2/2! + (xlnx)^3/3! + ...
And converges for all x values in the domain of x^x.

Although it kind of makes sense because x^x can be rearranged as e^(xlnx) therefore substituting in xlnx for all x's in the Taylor series for e^x will get you this polynomial series.

I'm just wondering about a quadratic with roots at +-pi/2, which works out to something like y=1-xx/2.476. I know this is beside the point you're trying to make about Taylor series, but since you're talking about approximating cos(x), I thought I might be able to figure out if my polynomial was in fact "closer" by integrating the area bounded between them from 0 to pi/2 and compare that to the Taylor quadratic. Turns out I was "right"! The average accuracy over that interval is better. In fact, when you integrate ~1-xx/2.66 - cos(x) from 0 to pi/2, the integral is ~0.

Guys, complete mind blown: how to approximate f(x) = x using Taylor series? Well

e^x = 1 + x + x^2/2! + x^3/3! + ...
e^(lnx) = 1 + (lnx) + (lnx)^2/2! + (lnx)^3/3! + ...
x = 1 + (lnx) + (lnx)^2/2! + (lnx)^3/3! + ...

This makes easy polynomials incredibly difficult to visualize and differentiate!
